snippet: The OraQuick test, which uses a mouth swab and gives results in 20 to 40 minutes, is the first method for Americans to learn in the privacy of their own homes whether they are infected.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration, following decades of controversy, approves an easy-to-use, home HIV test; OraQuick test, manufactured by OraSure Technologies, uses a mouth swab and gives results in 20 to 50 minutes; AIDS researchers hail approval as a positive step forward in combating the spread of the disease.
lead_paragraph: The OraQuick test, which uses a mouth swab and gives results in 20 to 40 minutes, is the first method for Americans to learn in the privacy of their own homes whether they are infected.

headline.seo: OraQuick At-Home H.I.V. Test Wins F.D.A. Approval
headline.main: Rapid H.I.V. Home Test Wins Federal Approval
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Approves Rapid H.I.V. Test For Use At Home
